The statue set up in the Capitol today came as a result of an additional rearrangement in 1976,which reduced overcrowding and improved the organization of the statues.

Happy #FunFact Friday!
https://history.house.gov/Exhibitions-and-Publications/Capitol/Becoming-Statuary-Hall/

By the 1930s, Congress had to pass another resolution to set standards for the relocation of statues and location of statues yet to come.

At the time, Statuary Hall had become crowded and disorganized, with some statues lined three rows deep.

Prior to the Congressman's proposal, the room was used as a thoroughfare and storage space, but once Statuary Hall began to take shape the idea was an immediate success. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FXuZyp2VEAAdrwv.jpg

Did you know? After the construction of the House Chamber in 1857, the previous chamber, now Statuary Hall, sat underutilized for several years.

It wasn't until 1864, that Congressman Morrill of Vermont had the idea of dedicating statues to each state in the old chamber. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FXuZU0kVEAMBwMO.jpg

8. Combatting Discrimination in Marijuana Sentencing¬†Amendment
The Military Justice Review Panel must recognize the historically discriminatory manner marijuana laws have been enforced & the ongoing risk of discrimination in conducting sentencing for marijuana offenses.

7. Inclusive Childcare¬†Amendment
Requires the study & report of childcare challenges on military bases emphasizing addressing challenges that shift based on population from base to base, such as ESL programs for bases with populations of non-English speaking children.

6. Screening for Lead Exposure Amendment
Expands a new DoD program to screen individuals with health conditions resulting from unsafe housing units to include screening for lead exposure.

5. Protecting Domestic Violence Survivors¬†Amendment
Assists victims of domestic violence in the military to ensure that their feedback is taken into account, and pilots a program to recommend potential ways that could be pursued to further safeguard domestic violence survivors.

4. Military Housing Feedback Tool¬†Amendment
Requires Military Housing Feedback Tools for those in DoD housing to have functionality that helps tenants identify safety hazards ‚Äì lead paint & pipes, asbestos, toxic mold, & non-functioning fire & carbon monoxide detection equipment.

3. Lead and Copper Rule Amendment
Directs DoD to issue a report to Congress on compliance with the Lead and Copper Rule in military installations, military housing, and privatized military housing to identify facilities where servicemembers lack access to clean water.

2. Veterans Credit¬†Amendment
Strengthens protections for servicemembers for medical debt collection & credit reporting. It prohibits collection of medical debt for two years & prohibits any medical debt from a medically necessary procedure from ever appearing on a credit report.

1. Improving Federal Housing Administration (FHA) Support for Small Dollar Mortgages Act¬†Amendment. 
This amendment adds our legislation H.R. 1532 to the NDAA. It requires the FHA to study, report on, & implement policies that will make small-dollar mortgages more viable.
